text: Transcription factors belonging to the NF-kappa B family are controlled by inhibitory I kappa B proteins , mainly <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> I kappa B beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Apparently normal at birth , <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - / - mice exhibit severe runting , skin defects , and extensive granulopoiesis postnatally , typically dying by 8 days .

Hematopoietic tissues from these mice display elevated levels of both nuclear NF-kappa B and mRNAs of some , but not all , genes thought to be regulated by NF-kappa B . NF-kappa B elevation results in these phenotypic abnormalities because mice lacking both <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and the <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> subunit of NF-kappa B show a dramatically delayed onset of abnormalities .

text: In contrast to hematopoietic cells , <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - / - embryonic fibroblasts show minimal constitutive NF-kappa B , as well as normal signal - dependent NF-kappa B activation that is concomitant with <extra_id_0> I kappa B beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> degradation .

text: Our results indicate that <extra_id_0> I kappa b beta <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , but not <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , is required for the signal - dependent activation of NF-kappa B in fibroblasts .
However , <extra_id_0> I kappa B alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is required for the postinduction repression of NF-kappa B in fibroblasts .
These results define distinct roles for the two forms of I kappa B and demonstrate the necessity for stringent control of NF-kappa B .
